description: Scene construction rules governing structure, purpose, entry/exit points, and narrative function

investigation_scenes.description: Crime scene analysis, evidence review, database searches

interrogation_scenes.description: Witness interviews, suspect questioning, informant meetings

character_scenes.description: Partner dynamics, personal life, relationship development

revelation_scenes.description: Breakthrough moments, case connections, puzzle pieces clicking

scene_structure.description: Every scene must follow goal-conflict-disaster or goal-conflict-resolution pattern

validations.name: scene-goal-clarity
validations.description: Reader must understand what character wants in this scene within first 100 words

examples.violation: Scene meanders with unclear purpose; reader unsure what character is trying to accomplish
examples.compliant: Detective enters precinct to review forensic report (clear goal), scene begins with her approaching lab door

validations.validation_query: What does the POV character want to achieve in this scene? When does reader learn this?

validations.name: conflict-obstacle-requirement
validations.description: Every scene must contain obstacle preventing easy achievement of goal

examples.violation: Detective wants forensic report, gets report, leaves (no conflict)
examples.compliant: Detective wants report but lab tech is defensive about contaminated evidence, requiring negotiation and revealing department tensions

validations.validation_query: What prevents the character from easily achieving their scene goal?

validations.name: scene-ending-impact
validations.description: Scene must end with yes-but, no-and, or no-but (never plain yes/no)

examples.violation: Detective gets exactly what they wanted with no complications (plain yes)
examples.compliant: Detective gets forensic report (yes) BUT it contradicts witness testimony, deepening mystery (yes-but)

validations.validation_query: How does this scene end? Does it create new questions, complications, or costs?

ending_patterns.yes_but: Character achieves goal BUT at a cost or with complication
ending_patterns.no_and: Character fails to achieve goal AND situation worsens
ending_patterns.no_but: Character fails to achieve goal BUT discovers alternative path or information

scene_purpose.description: Scenes must serve multiple narrative functions simultaneously

validations.name: dual-purpose-minimum
validations.description: Every scene must accomplish minimum 2 of: plot advancement, character development, worldbuilding, relationship dynamics, tension escalation

examples.violation: Scene only shows detective driving to location with no other content
examples.compliant: During drive, detective argues with partner about case approach (relationship dynamics) while receiving call about new lead (plot advancement)

validations.validation_query: List all narrative functions this scene serves. Are there at least 2?

validations.name: investigation-advancement
validations.description: Every 3rd scene must materially advance investigation (new clue, eliminated suspect, changed theory)

examples.violation: Five consecutive scenes with no change in detective's understanding of case
examples.compliant: Scene 1: character development, Scene 2: relationship dynamics, Scene 3: discovers crucial timeline discrepancy

validations.validation_query: When was the last scene that changed detective's understanding of the case?

validations.name: no-placeholder-scenes
validations.description: Scenes existing only to move characters from A to B must be cut or combined

examples.violation: Full scene of detective entering car, starting engine, driving, parking, exiting car
examples.compliant: Previous scene ends at precinct, next scene begins at crime scene with single transition line

validations.validation_query: What would be lost if this scene were summarized in one sentence?

scene_entry_exit.description: Scenes must begin late and end early to maintain momentum

validations.name: late-entry
validations.description: Enter scene as close to core conflict as possible; skip preliminaries

examples.violation: Scene starts with detective waking up, showering, eating breakfast, driving to precinct, walking to captain's office
examples.compliant: Scene opens mid-conversation with captain already underway: 'The mayor wants this case closed by Friday.'

validations.validation_query: Could this scene start later without losing critical information?

validations.name: early-exit
validations.description: Exit scene immediately after key moment; don't linger through denouement

examples.violation: Interrogation breaks suspect, then 300 words of detective leaving room, walking down hall, exiting building
examples.compliant: Suspect confesses. Hard cut to next scene.

validations.validation_query: Could this scene end earlier without losing impact?

validations.name: transition-efficiency
validations.description: Scene transitions should be single sentence or paragraph unless transition itself serves narrative purpose

examples.violation: Full paragraph describing walk from interrogation room to parking lot
examples.compliant: She left him in the interrogation room and headed for the precinct garage. (single sentence)

validations.validation_query: Does this transition contain information essential to plot/character/world?

investigation_scene_specifics.description: Detective procedural scenes have specific structural requirements

validations.name: crime-scene-examination-structure
validations.description: Crime scene investigations must balance: sensory details (20%), technical procedure (30%), deduction/theory (30%), character reaction (20%)

examples.violation: Pure technical description with no character response or deductive reasoning
examples.compliant: Sensory: blood pattern description → Technical: forensic tech's explanation → Deduction: detective's theory about sequence of events → Character: emotional impact of violence

validations.validation_query: What is the balance of elements in this crime scene investigation?

validations.name: clue-presentation
validations.description: Clues must be presented to reader with equal or slightly greater emphasis than red herrings

examples.violation: Critical clue mentioned in passing while red herring gets detailed focus
examples.compliant: Both genuine clue and red herring receive similar narrative attention, letting reader process both

validations.validation_query: Is this clue given appropriate narrative weight for reader to notice?

validations.name: evidence-chain-tracking
validations.description: Show evidence collection and processing to maintain procedural authenticity

examples.violation: Evidence appears in lab analysis with no mention of collection
examples.compliant: Detective bags evidence at scene → mentions sending to lab → later scene shows lab results

validations.validation_query: Has this evidence's chain of custody been established on-page?

interrogation_scene_specifics.description: Interview and interrogation scenes follow specific dramatic patterns

validations.name: interrogation-power-dynamics
validations.description: Interview scenes must establish and shift power balance between interviewer and subject

examples.violation: Flat interrogation where detective asks questions, witness answers cooperatively throughout
examples.compliant: Detective starts in control → witness deflects and gains upper hand → detective reveals evidence and reclaims power → witness cracks or stonewalls

validations.validation_query: How does the power dynamic shift during this interrogation?

validations.name: information-exchange-realism
validations.description: Witnesses/suspects should not volunteer key information without pressure or motivation

examples.violation: Witness unprompted confesses crucial details without detective asking
examples.compliant: Witness hedges → detective asks targeted question based on prior clue → witness reluctantly confirms → detective presses for details

validations.validation_query: What motivates this character to reveal information at this moment?

validations.name: interrogation-technique-variety
validations.description: Use varied interview approaches: rapport-building, direct accusation, evidence presentation, emotional appeal

examples.violation: Detective uses identical interrogation approach for every witness
examples.compliant: Frightened witness: rapport-building → Hostile suspect: evidence presentation → Grieving family: emotional appeal

validations.validation_query: Is this interview technique appropriate for this specific subject and situation?

magical_scene_integration.description: Urban fantasy elements must be integrated into scene structure, not tacked on

validations.name: magic-as-tool-not-solution
validations.description: Magical elements should complicate or provide partial information, not solve scene objective outright

examples.violation: Detective uses spell to instantly identify killer, scene ends
examples.compliant: Detective uses detection spell to confirm magical residue at scene, raising question of whether mundane investigation missed magical component

validations.validation_query: Does magic solve this scene's conflict or add complexity to it?

validations.name: mundane-magical-juxtaposition
validations.description: Urban fantasy scenes should blend everyday procedural elements with supernatural aspects

examples.violation: Entire scene takes place in purely magical realm divorced from urban setting
examples.compliant: Detective examines crime scene using standard forensics while noting magical wards that failed (blending mundane and magical)

validations.validation_query: Does this scene juxtapose mundane and magical elements?

agent_integration.bailey: Apply scene structure rules during drafting; ensure dual-purpose compliance
agent_integration.edna: Validate scene entry/exit timing and narrative efficiency
agent_integration.tessa: Check scene purpose continuity and investigation advancement tracking
agent_integration.miranda: Final approval of scene function across chapter arcs
